diagnosis.score_summary: This is an exceptionally disciplined brand. Aquaphor refuses to be charmed by trends on either channel, maintaining a rigid 'Medical Authority' status, though the Amazon page has evolved into a sports-utility tool while the website remains a medical library.

truth_1.headline: Patient vs. Athlete
truth_1.gap_description: The WWW treats the user like a patient seeking 'Sanctuary' (Self-Perception 1/5). The PDP treats the user like an athlete seeking 'Readiness' (Self-Perception 3/5). One is hiding from pain; the other is preparing for performance.
truth_1.why_matters: You are splitting the demographic. The website speaks to people with skin pathology (eczema, damage), while Amazon has successfully pivoted to the 'Gym Bag' crowd. You cannot be a hospital and a locker room simultaneously without confusing the use-case.
truth_1.the_hard_choice: You have inadvertently discovered a massive growth vertical on Amazon (Sports Utility) that your website ignores. You must decide: either pivot the global brand to 'Active Recovery' to capture the high-performance market (Option A), or discipline the Amazon listing back to 'Clinical Repair' to protect the medical purity (Option B). You are currently selling courage on one channel and caution on the other.

truth_2.headline: The Professor vs. The Robot
truth_2.gap_description: WWW uses 'The Clinical Authority' tone—using full sentences and academic grammar. PDP uses 'The Modern Minimalist'—stripping language down to efficient Q&A binary code ('Will it hurt? No.').
truth_2.evidence: WWW: 'Formulated with nourishing...' vs. PDP: 'Is this hypoallergenic? Yes.'
truth_2.why_matters: The website feels like a lecture; the Amazon page feels like a dashboard. The friction occurs when a user leaves the efficiency of Amazon and lands in the density of your site—it feels like walking into a library and being shushed.
truth_2.the_hard_choice: The Amazon data suggests users don't want to read your 'nourishing' adjectives; they want binary answers. The choice is clear: either strip the website copy down to raw utility to match the high-converting minimalism of the marketplace (Option A), or force the Amazon copy to adopt the 'Respectful' cadence of the brand guidelines (Option B). Efficiency is the enemy of poetry, and you must pick a side.

truth_3.headline: The Thesis vs. The Pitch
truth_3.gap_description: On WWW, the content intent is 'The Thesis' (1/5)—teaching the user about ingredients. On PDP, the intent jumps to 'The Pitch' (4/5)—selling the use-case. Same territory, vastly different aggression levels.
truth_3.evidence: Intent Vector: WWW (1/5 Thesis) vs. PDP (4/5 Pitch)
truth_3.why_matters: Your website is educating people who are already sold, while your Amazon page is selling to people who just want the product. The website is passive; the marketplace is active. This creates a 'funnel clog' where the Direct channel fails to close.
truth_3.the_hard_choice: You are treating your own website like a museum of dermatology rather than a store. You must decide: either accept the website is solely for education and stop measuring it on conversion (Option A), or inject the 'Pitch' dynamics from Amazon into the dot-com to actually move units (Option B). You cannot bore people into buying.

truth_4.headline: The Hero is Waking Up
truth_4.gap_description: The Archetype mix is Stable (80%), but a 'Hero' archetype (20%) has appeared on Amazon via the 'Active Lifestyle' imagery. This contradicts the pure 'Caregiver' control of the main brand.
truth_4.why_matters: The 'Hero' archetype creates an expectation of performance enhancement, not just damage control. If you let this grow unchecked on Amazon without supporting it globally, the brand loses its 'Medical' grounding and becomes just another 'Fitness' balm.
truth_4.the_hard_choice: The 'Hero' is converting, but it dilutes the 'Caregiver.' You face a strategic fork: either kill the 'Active Lifestyle' imagery to remain the #1 Dermatologist brand (Option A), or formally adopt the 'Hero' archetype into the global guidelines to evolve the brand into Performance Skincare (Option B). A doctor saves you; a hero empowers you. Which one are you?

truth_5.headline: The Power of Ugly
truth_5.gap_description: Both channels score 100% alignment on 'Pharma-Code' visuals. The refusal to use gradients, lifestyle fluff, or 'beauty' cues is absolute. You are winning because you look boring.
truth_5.why_matters: In a beauty category obsessed with 'Glow' and 'Vibe,' your clinical sterility acts as a super-signal for efficacy. You haven't fallen into the trap of trying to look 'premium.'
truth_5.the_hard_choice: Most brands try to 'elevate' their look and ruin their trust. Your hard choice is to double down: resist every urge from your creative agency to make the brand 'modern' or 'warm.' Stay cold. Stay blue. Stay ugly. It is the only reason people trust you with their cracked skin.

marker_1.so_what: A near-perfect lock on authority. Both channels agree that the brand exists to fix broken things, not to beautify them. The Amazon listing leans slightly harder into 'Cure' over 'Restore,' but the medical mandate is preserved.

marker_2.so_what: Total synchronization on scope and access. The brand knows it is a mass-market tool for specific micro-problems. There is no delusion of grandeur here; it is a democratized fix for the masses.

marker_3.so_what: The 'Do No Harm' prime directive is active on both channels. Whether it's 'Hypoallergenic' or 'Gentle,' the signal is that performance never comes at the cost of irritation. This is the bedrock of the brand's trust.

marker_4.so_what: The brand wears the uniform of the clinic perfectly. By keeping the aesthetic sterile and the value perception grounded in 'Essential Utility,' it avoids the 'Masstige' trap. It looks like medicine because it is positioned as medicine.

marker_5.so_what: The brand maintains professional distance. It doesn't try to be your best friend; it acts like a competent specialist. This coldness is actually a feature, not a bug—it signals objectivity.

marker_6.so_what: The primary 'Caregiver' archetype is solid, but Amazon introduces a 'Hero' streak via the active lifestyle context. The website is about 'Being Healed,' while Amazon is about 'Staying Active.' It's a subtle but distinct shift in motivation.

marker_7.so_what: The website speaks in paragraphs; the Amazon page speaks in data points. The shift from 'Academic' (WWW) to 'Robot' (PDP) creates a personality fracture—one is a doctor explaining a diagnosis, the other is a vending machine dispensing a product.

marker_8.so_what: A flawless execution of the 'Hospital' aesthetic. The discipline to stick to Navy, White, and Red without adding lifestyle softness is what gives the brand its authority. It looks like it belongs on a prescription pad.

marker_9.so_what: Both channels hook the user with 'Result' (Relief). The Amazon page pushes the logic slightly harder into 'Raw Data' (Percentages), but the mechanism of persuasion is identical: Identify Pain -> Apply Logic -> Promise Relief.

marker_10.so_what: The story is consistent because there is no story—only science. The protagonist is the 'Dermatologist' on both channels. By removing the human ego from the narrative, the brand amplifies the institutional trust.

marker_11.so_what: The validator (Derms) is consistent, but the proof changes. WWW relies on 'The List' (Free-from claims) while PDP relies on 'The Graph' (Clinical proof). It's a shift from 'Safe because of what isn't in it' to 'Effective because of what is in it.'

marker_12.so_what: On the website, 'Aquaphor' the name is the USP. On Amazon, the 'Stick Format' (The Tech) becomes the USP. This is a smart tactical adjustment for Amazon search intent, even if it creates a slight strategic drift.

marker_13.so_what: The 'Intent' slider reveals the friction. WWW is writing a thesis; PDP is making a pitch. The content on the site is designed to inform, while the content on the marketplace is weaponized to convert. It works, but it feels like two different departments wrote it.

marker_14.so_what: A solid lock on the mechanism of 'Healing.' The slight drift towards 'Sensory' on Amazon (emphasizing the non-sticky feel) is a necessary concession to the format (stick vs tube), but the core promise of restoration remains intact.

marker_15.so_what: This is the biggest psychological break. The website sells the 'Sanctuary' of safety to a suffering patient. The Amazon page sells the 'Readiness' of a gym-goer. You are selling a blanket on one channel and a sword on the other.

marker_16.so_what: Both channels agree: nobody buys this product to look cool. They buy it because it is the 'Standard' tool for the job. Embracing this lack of ego is what makes the brand so powerful in a vanity-driven market.

marker_17.so_what: The social contract is identical: buying Aquaphor is the safe, majority choice. It protects the user from the social risk of making a 'wrong' or 'weird' purchase decision. It is the beige sedan of skincare, and that is a compliment.
